SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A. MEETING OF EXAMINATION TO THE PERSON COMPLETING THIS QUESTIONNAIRE.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use your best efforts to answer all questions. If there is not sufficient space to answer the question, write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1917, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All Questionnaires

( ) Pioneer health conditions

( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation

( ) Pioneer housing

( ) Pioneer education and churchwork

( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,

University of Saskatchewan,

Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A. MEET OF QUESTIONNAIRE TO THE PERSON

B. COMPLETION OF THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use imagination or make up answers if there are not sufficient space to answer the question. Don't hesitate to give detailed or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family has answered the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

column all of us to get to America hope family are all right except one, for the States and Canada.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Some of them thought I was making a mistake, but the others seemed to agree.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

All alone.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

By steamboat.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

We left by boat on the 18th April and traveled via Quebec on the 25th May. The boat was getting very crowded so we had to stop a little while for breakfast to give us a little little rest. God willing we came to us a little little after 3 days away on the Allan Line.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Yakima.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Hillside where you'll find nine farms.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

In B.C., 2 years.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Working on a ranch.
